Award.AwardTitle: Constraining Tropical Low Cloud Feedbacks Using Observations of the Fast Cloud Response
Award.AbstractNarration:
Changes in the properties of low clouds in the tropics and subtropics in response to global warming have been identified as a key cause of the large uncertainty in global warming projections from climate models. In some models warming produces more prevalent or more reflective low clouds, thus reflecting more sunlight back to space and partially mitigating the warming effects of greenhouse gases (a negative cloud feedback to the imposed warming), while in other models the clouds become less reflective or less prevalent and enhanced sunlight at the surface exacerbates global warming (a positive cloud feedback). This research attempts to produce observationally-constrained estimates of the true low cloud feedback using a combination of satellite observations, reanalysis products, and climate model outputs. The method first uses a neural network to establish empirical relationships between low cloud reflectivity and other cloud properties (determined from satellite observations) and large-scale variables including sea surface temperature and atmospheric temperature and water vapor. These relationships are established using the fast (timescales of hours to a day) response of clouds to their environment. Once these relationships are established, cloud feedback will estimated by applying the empirical relationships represented by the neural network in combination with changes in the large-scale variables in the climate models which occur as a result of simulated global warming. In addition to estimates of the low cloud feedback to global warming, the method will provide uncertainty bounds for those estimates, and can be used to diagnose errors in model parameterizations of low cloud properties.

The work has broader impacts due to the key role of tropical low cloud feedback in generating the large uncertainty in model projections of climate change. A reliable, observationally-based estimate of the low cloud feedback could help to reduce this uncertainty and provide better information to decision makers regarding the likely extent and physical consequences of greenhouse-gas induced global warming.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Uncertainty about the future of the climate system comes from uncertain feedbacks — that is, changes to the earth system that dampen or amplify a temperature change. The melting of ice caps, for example, is a positive feedback because warmer temperatures melt more ice, which lets the earth absorb more sunlight, leading to even more warming. By far the most uncertain feedbacks are those related to clouds. Much of the diversity in estimates of future change by climate models can be traced to different feedbacks in low clouds over the ocean, which are particularly important because they are effective at reflecting sunlight and cooling the planet, but so small compared to the size of the atmosphere that they must be treated quite abstractly in climate models. 

This project estimated the changes that might occur in low clouds in future climates based on how they vary from today’s world, exploiting the fact that climate changes in the next century are small compared to day-to-day and place-to-place variations in the present.  We combined specialized satellite observations measuring the sunlight reflected by clouds with estimates of atmospheric temperature, winds, and humidity used in weather forecasts (and incorporating many observations). From these we developed statistical descriptions of how reflectivity depends on atmospheric conditions. Our work was unique in covering the whole of the Tropics where other studies had focused on small areas containing the brightest clouds, and in trading smooth long-term averages for noisy observations made every day, because that’s the time scale on which clouds respond to atmospheric conditions. 

Then we asked how atmospheric conditions are likely to change in future climates. For this we turned to climate models, which are much better at predicting broad changes in temperatures, winds, and so on than they are at predicting clouds, and extracted atmospheric conditions from simplified experiments in which the ocean temperature is warmed uniformly in comparison to today’s conditions, breaking the feedback loop on surface temperature. We then applied the statistical relationships we had determined from observations to future atmospheric conditions. Using a range of climate models to determine possible changes in future conditions lets us assess how robust our conclusions are. No matter what set of warmer conditions we used we found that low clouds over the ocean become dimmer as the climate warm at a pace that’s two to four times larger than predicted by the climate models themselves. This means that positive feedbacks from oceanic low clouds are nearly certain. Combined with better knowledge of other clouds feedbacks, like the increase in the height to which the deepest cloud in the tropics rise, our work helps rule out negative cloud feedbacks.
